conjugations.kikuyu: Nda/ Nda | | **hand** | Rũhĩ/ Hĩ | | **waist** | Njohero/ Njohero | | **knee** | Îru/ Maru | | **fingers** | Kĩara/ Twara | | **leg** | Kũgũrũ/ Magũrũ | | **foot** | Ikĩnya/ Makĩnya | | **toes** | Kĩara/ Twara | *** ## Nuclear Family and Dialogue This vocabulary and dialogue are taken from the image illustrating the family: | Kikuyu Phrase | English Translation | Context/Notes | |:---|:---|:---| | **Ũyũ nĩ baba** | This is father | Father is taking photographs. | | **Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ maitũ** | This other one is mother | | | **Tũrũgamĩte na mwarĩ wa maitũ** | We are standing with my sister | Literally: "We are standing with the daughter of my mother." | | **Ũcio mũraihu nĩ mama** | The tall one is my uncle (mother's side) | **Mama** refers to the maternal uncle. | | **Baba arahũra mbica** | Father is taking photographs | | | **Mwarimũ:** Maina rũgama | **Teacher:** Maina, stand up | | | **Maina:** Nĩ ndarũgama mwarimũ | **Maina:** I have stood up teacher | | | **Mwarimũ:** Ũyũ nũũ ? | **Teacher:** Who is this | Asking about the father. | | **Maina:** Ũyũ nĩ baba | **Maina:** This is father | | | **Mwarimũ:** Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ nũũ ? | **Teacher:** Who is this other one? | Asking about the mother. | | **Maina:** Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ maitũ | **Maina:** This other one is mother | | | **Mwarimũ:** Mũrũgamĩte naũ? | **Teacher:** Who are you standing with? | | | **Maina:** Tũrũgamĩte na Mwarĩ wa maitũ | **Maina:** We are standing with my sister | | | **Mwarimũ:** Ĩkara thĩ | **Teacher:** Sit down | | *** *The vertical text on both images reads: **Learn Kikuyu
conjugations.cultural_notes: Native speaker verb conjugation examples from Easy Kikuyu lessons

conjugations.kikuyu: Nda/ Nda | | **hand** | Rũhĩ/ Hĩ | | **waist** | Njohero/ Njohero | | **knee** | Îru/ Maru | | **fingers** | Kĩara/ Twara | | **leg** | Kũgũrũ/ Magũrũ | | **foot** | Ikĩnya/ Makĩnya | | **toes** | Kĩara/ Twara | *** ## 2. Health and Hospital Phrases This section provides vocabulary and common phrases related to illness and visiting a hospital (**Thibitarĩ**). ### Vocabulary | Kikuyu Term | English Meaning | Image Context | |:---|:---|:---| | **Thibitarĩ** | Hospital | Building exterior | | **Mũrwaru** | Patient / Sick person | Person on a hospital bed | | **Ndagĩtarĩ** | Doctor (male) | Man in a lab coat | | **Mũrigitani** | Doctor (female/general term) | Woman in a lab coat | | **Dagĩtarĩ wa magego** | Dentist | Person sitting in a dental chair | | **Mĩthaiga** | Medicine / Drugs | Pills and bottles | | **Ndawa** | Medicine / Remedy | Pills and bottles | ### Dialogue and Phrases | Kikuyu Phrase | English Translation | |:---|:---| | **Ndĩ mũrwaru** | I am sick | | **Ndiraiguia wega** | I am not feeling well | | **Thĩĩ thibitarĩ** | Go to the hospital | | **Ũraatũũrwo nĩ kũ?** | Where are you hurting (where is your pain)? | | **Ndiraatũũrwo nĩ mũtwee** | I have a headache | | **Nĩ ũraatũũrwo nĩ nda?** | Do you have a stomachache? | | **Aca ndiraatũũrwo nĩ nda** | No I do not have a stomachache | | **Ũraatũũrwo nĩ kũũ ũngĩ?** | Where else are you hurting? | | **O na igego nĩ rĩraatũũra** | I also have a toothache | | **Thĩĩ wone ndagĩtarĩ wa magego** | Go see a dentist | | **Eha mũrigitanĩ** | Where is the nurse? | | **Amba ũthĩmwo ratirĩ** | Get your weight checked first | | **Hĩĩ! Wĩ na ũrugarĩ!** | Wah! Your temperature is high | *** *The vertical text on both images reads: **Learn Kikuyu

conjugations.kikuyu: Ndigũkwĩra ũrĩa njĩtagwo** | I will not tell you my name | 1st Person Singular Future Negative (*Ndi-gũ...*) | | **Nĩ waragia Gĩkũyũ?** | Do you speak Kĩkũyũ? | Question (Present Tense) | | **Ndiaragia Gĩkũyũ o na hanini** | I don't speak Kĩkũyũ (even a little) | 1st Person Singular Present Negative (*Ndi-a...*) | | **Mũgai nĩ aragia Gĩkũyũ?** | Does Mũgai speak...? | Question (Present Tense) | | **Mũgai ndaragia Gĩkũyũ** | Mũgai does not speak Kĩkũyũ | 3rd Person Singular Present Negative (*Nda-ra...*) | | **O na Gĩthweri tũtĩaragia** | Even Swahili we do not speak (We also don't speak Swahili) | 1st Person Plural Present Negative (*Tũ-tĩ-a...*) | | **Aria kahora** | Speak slowly | Positive imperative (Command) | | **Ndĩkwaria kahora** | I will not speak slowly | 1st Person Singular Future Negative (*Ndi-kũ...*) | | **Tũtĩkwaria Kahora** | We will not speak slowly | 1st Person Plural Future Negative (*Tũ-tĩ-kũ...*) | | **Atĩ mũtĩkwaria kahora?** | So you will not ......? (So you all will not speak slowly?) | 2nd Person Plural Future Negative Question (*Mũ-tĩ-kũ...*) | | **Moiga matĩkwaria kahora** | They have said they will not speak slowly | 3rd Person Plural Future Negative (*Ma-tĩ-kũ...*) | | **O na wee ndũkwaria kahora?** | Even you, you will not speak slowly? | 2nd Person Singular Future Negative Question (*Ndũ-kũ...*) | | **Thĩĩ mũciĩ na ihenya** | Go home fast (Quickly) | Positive imperative (Command) | | **Ndigũthĩĩ** | I will not go. | 1st Person Singular Future Negative (*Ndi-gũ...*) | *** **Learn Kĩkũyũ

conjugations.kikuyu: Ndigiri ĩno nĩ ya Wajir** * **Translation:** This donkey is from Wajir; It is found in Wajir; it belongs to Wajir. * **Nĩmũrona ũrĩa ĩmenye-reirwo do you (all) see** * **Translation:** Do you (all) see how it has been taken care of? --- ### Key Vocabulary and Grammar | Kikuyu Word/Phrase | Literal Meaning/Grammar Note | | :--- | :--- | | **Ndigiri** | **Donkey** (The authentic Kikuyu word; *Bunda* or *Ng'unda* are also used by some people) | | **Ĩno** | **This one** (Demonstrative for noun class N/N $\rightarrow$ **ici** is the plural: **These ones**) | | **Nĩ ũrona?** | **Can you see? vocabulary.english: week 4 - 4 11. Ĩkũmi na ĩmwe - eleven 12. Ĩkũmi na ĩgĩrĩ - twelve 13. Ĩkũmi na ĩthatũ - thirteen We take a break from this progression and move on to number twenty. The archaic term for ten is "Mũrongo." It is used from number twenty onwards. 20. Mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ (literally two tens). 21. Mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ na ĩmwe, 22. Mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ na ĩgĩrĩĩ This goes on to 30. Mĩrongo ĩtatũ until we get to 99. Mĩrongo kenda na kenda The following are three digit numbers starting with 100. 100. Igana rĩmwe, 101. Igana rĩmwe na ĩmwe, 102. Igana rĩmwe na ĩgĩrĩĩ 120. Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ - one hundred and twenty 141. Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo ĩna na ĩmwe. 199. Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo kenda na kenda. 1000. Ngiri ĩmwe - one thousand. For 'one million' we use a term borrowed from English - million 1000000. Mirioni ĩmwe - One million

vocabulary.kikuyu: This image is an excellent guide for learning some key aspects of Kikuyu pronunciation. ## Kikuyu Pronunciation Guide The word at the top, **Nĩtwĩrĩririkanie**, means **"Let us remember"** (literally: "remind ourselves"). The guide then provides phonetic examples for the key vowels and a couple of consonants: ### Vowels Kikuyu has seven cardinal vowels, some of which are marked with a tilde (~), a diaeresis (¨), or an acute accent (´) in other texts to show the two different degrees of openness for the same sound. This guide uses the tilde to distinguish them.

vocabulary.kikuyu: The image provides a vocabulary list for the major organs of the human **digestive system** in Kikuyu. The title, **Ciĩga cia njĩra ya irio**, translates to: * **Ciĩga** means **parts** or **organs**. * **cia** means **of the**. * **njĩra** means **way** or **path**. * **ya** means **of**. * **irio** means **food**. * So, **Ciĩga cia njĩra ya irio** literally means **"The parts of the path of food"** or **"The digestive system."** --- ## Kikuyu Digestive System Vocabulary Here are the Kikuyu terms for the organs labeled in the diagram:

vocabulary.english: forgive me learners Nĩ ndĩrathiĩte karũtha kanini – I had gone for a short leave (rũtha – permission, also means leave). ‘ka’ before a word diminishes it to small so “karutha” is a small leave. Now that I am forgiven let’s proceed with today’s lesson. IRIO CIA MŨGIKŨYŨ – FOOD OF THE KIKUYU Note that this is just a lesson. Kikuyus today eat everything like everybody else. IRIO CIA RŨCIĨNĨ – FOOD OF THE MORNING (BREAKFAST) Cai kana ũcũrũ – tea or porridge Mũgate kana ngwacĩ – bread or sweet potato Ndũma kana mĩanga – Arrow root or cassava mũthigwiti - buiscuit; keki - cake IRIO CIA MŨTHENYA – FOOD FOR DAYTIME (LUNCH) Gĩtheri kana mũkimo – maize and beans (githeri) or mashed food (mukimo - usually bananas and any cereal with some greens). IRIO CIA HWAIĨNĨ – FOOD FOR THE EVENING Ngima kana mũcere – ugali (posho) or rice Cabaci kana ndũma na gĩtoero – chapatti or arrow root and stew (gitoero – any stew) Iria imata kana nyama na ngima – fermented milk or milk and ugali Kũmata – to ferment (also ‘to be foolish’) Kũgagata – to ferment, to be acidic (also to be sarcastic) Irio ciĩna cama – the food is tasty Irio ciĩna mūrīo – the food is sweet Irio ciĩna cumbī mũingi – the food has too much salt (cumbī mũingi) Cai nĩ mũcamũ cukari – the tea has enough sugar Gũcama – to taste, to have enough of whatever additive. MĪRUGĨRE – METHODS OF COOKING Gũtherũkia – to boil Gũkaranga – to fry Kũhĩhia – to roast IRIO INGĨ - OTHER FOODS Marigũ methĩ – raw bananas Marigũ meru – ripe bananas Gĩkwa - yam Mbembe - maize mboco - beans minji - peas https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=1301340073247047&set=pb.100063609806723.-2207520000 -----------

proverb.kikuyu: You've uploaded several images containing Kikuyu language lessons, covering vocabulary, grammar, and sentence structure. Here is a compilation and synthesis of the information presented in those images. *** ## 1. Grammar: Future Tenses (Second Person Singular) The images illustrate the **Second Person Singular** (you) future tense, which has different prefixes depending on the time frame. ### ⏳ A Few Moments Later or Anytime Today The prefixes used for actions happening soon are **Ûgû-, Ûgwî-, Ûkwî-,** and **Ûkû-**. | Example | Translation | Prefix | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Ûgûkîra** dagîka ikûmi ciathira. | You will wake up after ten minutes. | Ûgû- | | **Ûgwîthamba** na maî mahoro. | You will take a bath with cold water. | Ûgwî- | | **Ûkwîhumba** nguo naihenya. | You will put on your clothes quickly. | Ûkwî- | ### 🗓️ Anytime Tomorrow and Into the Future The prefixes used for actions happening tomorrow or beyond are **Ûgo-, Ûge-, Ûke-,** and **Ûga-**. | Example | Translation | Prefix | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Ûgokîra** dagîka ikûmi ciathira. | You will wake up ten after ten minutes. | Ûgo- | | **Ûgethamba** na maî mahoro. | You will take a bath with cold water. | Ûge- | | **Ûkehumba** nguo naihenya. | You will put on your clothes quickly. | Ûke- | | **Ûkaruga** caî. | You will make tea. | Ûka- | *** ## 2. Vocabulary: Types of Houses (*Mîthemba ya Nyûmba*) The lessons cover three main types of traditional and modern houses, focusing on construction materials. | Type of House | Kikuyu Term | Construction Material | Roofing Material | Other Feature | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Stone House** | **Nyûmba ya Mahiga** | **Mahiga** (stones) | **Mabati** (iron sheets) | **Rûthingo rwa mahiga** (stone wall) | | **Timber House** | **Nyûmba ya mbaû** | **Mbaû** (timber/wood) | **Maturubarĩ** (tiles) | **Rûthingo rwa mbaû** (wooden wall) | | **Mud Hut** | **Nyûmba ya ndooro** | **Ndooro** (mud) | **Nyeki** (grass) or **ithanjĩ** (reeds) | **Rûthingo rwa ndooro** (mud wall) | *** ## 3. Vocabulary: Fauna and Weather ### 🐾 Insects (*Tûnyamû tûnyinyi*) | Kikuyu | English | Notes | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Mûthûa** | Termite | | | **Thûraku** | Soldier ant | Moves in a line. | | **Thigiriri** | Black ant | Small black ants. | | **Mûgagaca** | Fire ant | Very tiny brown ants that move in large groups. | ### 🐦 Birds (*Nyoni*) | Kikuyu | Scientific Name | English Name | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Kanyua njui** | *Cinnyris mediocris* | Sunbird | | **Gĩchorogothu** | *Pycnonotus barbatus* | Common bulbul | | **Ngũgũ** | *Tauraco hartlaubi* | Hartlaub's Turaco | ### ⛈️ Weather and Seasons (*Hîndî ya Mbura na ya riua*) | Kikuyu | English | Notes | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Rûheni** | Lightening | Comes before **marurumĩ** (thunder). | | **Mbura nî ya ringa** | The rain has started | Literally: 'the rain has beaten'. | | **Nî kûrathuthua** | It is drizzling | | | **Ime** | Dew | | | **Matu ma mbura** | Rain clouds | The grey ones. | | **Rûkûngû** | Dust | | | **Kigûû** | Flash flood | This word means *water* in Kikamba. | | **Thano** | Very dry season | | | **Mûkûnga mbura** | Rainbow | | | **Kwîna kibii** | There is fog | | *** ## 4. Grammar: Kikuyu Pronoun Table The image provides an overview of various pronouns and their variations due to noun class. | Category | Singular | Plural | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **I, me, myself** | **Nîî** | **(We, ourself) ithuî** | | **You** | **Wëë** | **Inyuî** | | **He, she** | **Wë** | **(Them) O** | | **mine** | Wakwa, Gĩakwa, gakwa, yakwa, rĩakwa | Ciakwa, Akwa, Makwa, twakwa | | **yours** | Gĩaku, gaku, yaku, waku, rĩaku | Ciaku, Twaku, ma-ku, aku | | **His/hers** | Gĩake, gake, yake, wake, rĩake | Ciake, Twake, make, ake | | **Theirs'** | Kĩao, kao, yao, rĩao, wao | Cĩao, Twao, mao, ao | | **it** | Kĩo, ko, yo, guo, rĩo | Cĩo, yo, mo, o | | **Who?** | **Ûû?** | **A?** | | **Anybody** | **Mûndû o wothe** | **Andû o

proverb.kikuyu: Around your sitting room.** | Kikuyu Word | English Word | | :--- | :--- | | **Mũrango** | Door | | **Kabati** | Cupboard | | **Metha** | Table | | **Nđirica** | Window | | **Gĩtĩ** | Chair | | **Gaturwa / Njĩngwa** | Stool | --- ## Text from Image 2: Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi (Kikuyu Creation Story) **Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi** **Aciari a rũrĩrĩ rwa Gĩkũyũ nĩ a ?** Who are the parents of the kikuyu tribe? **Aciari a rũrĩrĩ rwa Gĩkũyũ nĩ Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi** The parents of the Kikuyu are Gĩkũyũ and Mũũmbi **Maarĩ na ciana cigana?** How many children did they have? **Marĩ na ciana kenda** They had nine children. **Kenda mũiyũrũ** - the full nine (ten) **Tũhĩĩ kana tũirĩtu?** Girls or boys? **Tũirĩtu** - Girls. | Kikuyu Word | English Meaning | | :--- | :--- | | **Rũrĩrĩ** | a community speaking one language | | **Nyũmba** | house (traditionally woman's hut) | | **Thingira** | hut (traditionally for men) | | **Ikũmbĩ** | granary | | **Mũgũnda** | garden, farm. **Gĩcagi** - a village | --- ## Text from Image 3: Jobs **Jobs** **(Nĩĩ) Nđĩ bundi** - I am a handyman (carpenter, plumber etc.) **Nđutaga wĩra wa mbaũ** - I work with timber **. (Wee) wĩ mũrĩmi** - You are a farmer **Ũrutaga wĩra wa mũgũnda** - You work in a farm **. (We) nĩ ndereba** - he/she is a driver **. mixed.kikuyu: This looks like a great way to start learning **Kikuyu**! Combining the words you have here is a perfect exercise. Here are ten simple sentences formed by combining the verbs and nouns from your image: ## Simple Kikuyu Sentences 🇰🇪 1. **Ũka haha.** $\rightarrow$ Come here. 2. **Andĩka marũa.** $\rightarrow$ Write a letter. 3. **Rĩra maĩ.** $\rightarrow$ Cry for water. (This could also mean "Cry water," depending on context, but "cry for water" is a common simple expression). 4. **Theka mũthũuri.** $\rightarrow$ Laugh at the man. 5. **Rĩa irio.** $\rightarrow$ Eat food. 6. **Aria na mwanake.** $\rightarrow$ Speak with the young man. 7. **Thii wĩra.** $\rightarrow$ Go to work. 8. **Thooma marũa.** $\rightarrow$ Read a letter. 9. **Ruga ũcũrũ.** $\rightarrow$ Cook porridge. 10. **Mũirĩtu aruta wĩra.** $\rightarrow$ The girl is doing work. (Literally: Girl remove/do work). --- ### A Few Bonus Sentences! ✨ Here are a few more using the remaining words for extra practice: * **Kira, mũtumia.** $\rightarrow$ Keep quiet, woman. * **Ruta irio.** $\rightarrow$ Remove the food. * **Mũthũuri arĩa irio.** $\rightarrow$ The man is eating food. Let me know if you'd like to try translating any of those sentences back into English or if you have another list of words you'd like to work

Therefore, Uma nja can also mean "Come from outside

mixed.kikuyu: Here is the transcription and translation of the Kikuyu story titled "Karũgano ka Wambũi Mĩcore na Njogu" (Story of Zebra and Elephant), presented in plain text: *** ## Transcription and Translation: Story of Zebra and Elephant **Karũgano ka Wambũi Mĩcore na Njogu** - **Translation** **Story of Zebra and Elephant** * **Wambũi Mĩcore** - **Zebra** * **yarĩ ĩmwe ya nyamũ** - **was one of the animals** * **irĩa ciarĩ thaka mũno** - **that were most beautiful** * **bũrũriinĩ wa nyamũ** - **in the country of animals** * **Yarĩ na rũũa rũthaka** - **it had a beautiful hide (skin)** * **rwa mĩkarara mĩerũ na mĩirũ** - **with black and white stripes** * **Nyamũ ciothe** - **all the animals** * **ciamĩroragĩra ĩgegete mũno** - **looked at (Zebra) in awe** * **Nyamũ cionaga** - **the animals saw** * **ĩrĩ ya mathekania mũno** - **as very funny** * **Yatũmaga matheke** - **it made them laugh** * **kinya makoma mbaru** - **until their ribs ached (hardened)** * **Mamĩũragia atĩrĩrĩ** - **They used to ask it...** * **Mĩcore, ũhũraga thũ cĩaku atĩa?** - **Striped one, how do you fight your enemies?** * **Mĩcore yarũgamaga** - **The striped one would stand** * **na magũrũ ma mbere** - **with the forelegs** * **ĩgaikĩia mateke** - **and kicked** * **na magũrũ ma thutha** - **with the rear legs** * **Nyamũ ciothe** - **all the animals** * **cĩagũagĩa na mũtheko** - **fell down laughing (broke into laughter)** * **Hĩtĩ nĩyo yathekaga** - **hyena is the one that laughed** * **na mũgambo mũnene** - **in a loud voice** * **gũkĩra nyamũ irĩa ingĩ** - **than all the other animals** * **O na ũmũthĩ** - **even today** * **hĩtĩ yarĩrikana** - **when hyena remembers** * **ũrĩa Wambũi Mĩcore** - **how the zebra** * **ĩrũaga** - **fights** * **ĩthekaga ĩrĩ ĩkĩ ũtuko** - **it laughs alone in the night** (A faded watermark vertically on the right side
